linkTarget.anchoringText: The Oriente basin is located to the east of Ecuadorian Andes is the most prolific segment of the Putumayo-Oriente-Marañon oil province, which typically is subdivided in the following formations: Basal Tena, M1, M2, "U", "T" and Hollín. It contains three petroleum plays, Sub Andean system or West Play, Sacha Sushufindi Corridor or Central Play and Capiron Tiputini System or East Play, each of them with their own trap, reservoir and crude oil characteristics, Fig. 1, (Baby, 2004).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Main fields, plays and reservoirs in the Oriente basin API BUBBLE POINT PRESSURE VISCOSITY AT BUBBLE POINT PRESSURE

formatted-caption.caption-text: Main fields, plays and reservoirs in the Oriente basin API BUBBLE POINT PRESSURE VISCOSITY AT BUBBLE POINT PRESSURE

linkTarget.anchoringText: This section shows average, minimum and maximum values for bubble point pressure, GOR, OFVFpb, live oil viscosity at buble point pressure and API gravity for each reservoir by play, Table 1 to Table 5. Maps of API, bubble point pressure and viscosity are also shown in Fig. 2 to Fig. 6. The API data involves around 85% of the producing wells and PVT data was compiled from 318 laboratory reports.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This classification consists on typical values of different common measured properties at initial reservoir conditions for each crude oil type. This classification, Table 6, (Lake, 2007) is shown in Fig.7 in form of horizontal bars, samples from Oriente basin (dots) are ordered from shallower, Basal Tena, to deeper, Hollin sandstone in the vertical scale and the few samples from San Pablo – Pacoa basin (triangles) have no depth correlation. From this Fig. 7, initial molecular weight C7+and GOR, most samples lie in the range of heavy oils and some samples in the black oil range.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Crude oil classification by properties range

formatted-caption.caption-text: Crude oil classification by properties range

linkTarget.anchoringText: This classification method relies in the initial molecular weight to differenciate crude oils (Lake, 2007; Danesh, 1998) and relates with the behavior of initial OFVF and GOR, Fig.8. The values used in this classification are:

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Crude oil classification by properties and composition at initial conditions

formatted-caption.caption-text: Crude oil classification by properties and composition at initial conditions

linkTarget.anchoringText: The third definition (Gray, 2010) uses the viscosity at reservoir temperature and the API gravity, Fig.9.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Crude oil classification by viscosity and API gravity

formatted-caption.caption-text: Crude oil classification by viscosity and API gravity

linkTarget.anchoringText: This classification uses the phase behavior to define crude oil (Craft, 1991;Wheaton, 2016). The average composition, Table 7, for each reservoir was used to generate the phase envelopes shown in Fig.10. It must be noted that even though some PVT samples show higher and lower values for bubble point pressure, the objective of this plot is to show the differences in phase behavior for different crude oils compared with Ecuadorian crude oils.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Average phase envelopes of Ecuadorian crude oils

formatted-caption.caption-text: Average phase envelopes of Ecuadorian crude oils

linkTarget.anchoringText: Composition for typical reservoir fluids (Whitson, 2000) used in this classification is shown in Table 7 and Fig.11 (black oil composition is highlighted in blue). Composition from laboratory samples are shown as dots and the play is differentiated by color.

Reports with complete analysis were selected for separator adjustment (OFVF and GOR); those with nonphysical trends were disregarded. Quality check on composition data was performed (Lawrence, 2009). Data was classified by Basin´s play and Reservoir basis. On valid data, literature procedures were followed to generate a correlation from laboratory data as first approach (OFVF, GOR, bubble point pressure and live oil viscosity). The application of each correlation was proved by comparing the properties range from which the correlation was developed against the sample data, results for different properties and some samples are shown in Fig.12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Correlation application range vs laboratory samples

formatted-caption.caption-text: Correlation application range vs laboratory samples

linkTarget.anchoringText: The following bubble point pressure at reservoir temperature correlations were evaluated: Standing, 1947, Al-Marhourn, 1988, Dokla-Osman, 1992, Velarde et al, 1997. Statistical results are presented in Table 8, generic form of correlations is presented in Appendix A, Table 13, original and modified coefficients are presented in Appendix B, Table 18 and graphical comparison of measured and calculated values with modified coefficients is presented in Appendix C, Fig. C-13

image-wrap.label: Figure C-13
image-wrap.caption: Graphical comparison of calculated and measured data for bubble point pressure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Graphical comparison of calculated and measured data for bubble point pressure

linkTarget.anchoringText: The following gas oil ratio at bubble point pressure and reservoir temperature correlations were evaluated: Standing, 1947, Petrosky-Farshad, 1993, Al-Marhoun, 1988, and Hemmati-Kharrat, 2007. Statistical results are presented in Table 9, generic form of correlations is presented in Appendix A, Table 14, original and modified coefficients are presented in Appendix B, Table 19 and graphical comparison of measured and calculated values with modified coefficients is presented in Appendix C, Fig. C-14.

image-wrap.label: Figure C-14
image-wrap.caption: Graphical comparison of calculated and measured data for gas oil ratio

formatted-caption.caption-text: Graphical comparison of calculated and measured data for gas oil ratio

linkTarget.anchoringText: The following oil formation volume factor at bubble point pressure and reservoir temperature correlations were evaluated: Al-Marhoun, 1988, 1992, Dokla-Osman, 1992, Almehaideb, 1997, Al-Shammasi, 1999. Statistical results are presented in Table 10, generic form of correlations is presented in Appendix A, Table 15, original and modified coefficients are presented in Appendix B, Table 20 and graphical comparison of measured and calculated values with modified coefficients is presented in Appendix C, Fig.C-15.

image-wrap.label: Figure C-15
image-wrap.caption: Graphical comparison of calculated and measured data for oil formation volume factor

formatted-caption.caption-text: Graphical comparison of calculated and measured data for oil formation volume factor

linkTarget.anchoringText: The following dead oil viscosities at atmospheric pressure and reservoir temperature correlations were evaluated: Beal, 1946, Beggs-Robinson, 1975, Kartoatmodjo-Schmidt, 1991, Petrosky-Farshad, 1995. Statistical results are presented in Table 11, generic form of correlations is presented in Appendix A, Table 16, original and modified coefficients are presented in Appendix B, Table 21 and graphical comparison of measured and calculated values with modified coefficients is presented in Appendix C, Fig. C-16.

image-wrap.label: Figure C-16
image-wrap.caption: Graphical comparison of calculated and measured data for dead oil viscosity

formatted-caption.caption-text: Graphical comparison of calculated and measured data for dead oil viscosity

linkTarget.anchoringText: The following live oil viscosities at bubble point pressure and reservoir temperature correlations were evaluated: Khan et al, 1987, Almehaideb, 1997. Statistical results are presented in Table 12, generic form of correlations is presented in Appendix A, Table 17, original and modified coefficients are presented in Appendix B, Table 22 and graphical comparison of measured and calculated values with modified coefficients is presented in Appendix C, Fig. C-17.

image-wrap.caption: Graphical comparison of calculated and measured data for live oil viscosity
